Award.AwardTitle: Circulation and Transport in the Hudson Shelf Valley
Award.AbstractNarration:
It has long been known that submarine valleys over continental shelves and submarine canyons over continental slopes provide important pathways for transporting material such as sediment, nutrients and biological organisms across continental shelves and slopes. Previous studies have focused almost exclusively on deeper continental slope canyons. In contrast to slope canyons, shallower shelf valleys are strongly influenced by surface and bottom forcing, such as winds and waves, and often subject to large seasonal variations in stratification. Also in contrast to slope canyons, shelf valleys extend into shallow water, where sediment transport and biological processes are particularly active, and can therefore potentially facilitate cross-shelf transport of sediment and upwelling of nutrients to the near-surface euphotic zone. Shelf valleys provide a direct connection between the shelf region that is most strongly impacted by human activity and deep waters of the continental slope and open ocean.

The research objectives are guided by previous studies of slope canyons and preliminary analysis of observations in Hudson Shelf Valley, a narrow and long valley that cuts across the continental shelf of the Middle Atlantic Bight. Along-valley (cross-shelf) flows in Hudson Shelf Valley are primarily wind-driven and often reach 50 cm/s, an order of magnitude larger than cross-shelf flows on the adjacent continental shelf, making it an important conduit for cross-shelf exchange. The goal is a quantitative understanding of the response of flows in shelf valleys, particularly the along-valley transport, to wind forcing that will be broadly relevant to a wide range of shelf valleys. The approach is a sequence of idealized numerical modeling runs aimed at understanding the dynamics and quantifying the transport and vertical structure of the flow in shelf valleys in terms of relevant non-dimensional parameters, and complemented by analysis of existing observations from Hudson Shelf Valley and more realistic simulations of Hudson Shelf Valley to evaluate the relevance of the idealized model results to a realistic shelf valley. Analysis of historical observations and numerical simulations will be used to address fundamental scientific questions concerning the circulation and transport in shelf valleys and the contribution of valley flows to heat, salt and nutrient balances on the shelf.

Broader impacts: Better understanding of the circulation and transport in shelf valleys, and specifically Hudson Shelf Valley, will provide the physical background for studies of biological productivity and contaminant/larval dispersal on the shelf. It will also help quantify tracer and momentum exchanges between the continental shelf and the slope sea. The project will have educational impacts through the involvement of a full-time graduate student and participation by undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is aimed at understanding circulations in submarine valleys over continental shelves and submarine canyons over continental slopes. One example of a continental shelf valley is the Hudson Shelf Valley, which cuts through much of the Mid-Atlantic Bight continental shelf and connects the Hudson Estuary to the outer shelf. There are also valleys on other continental shelves in the global ocean. This type of geological feature often causes strong cross-shelf flow and facilitates the cross-shelf exchange of physical, biological and chemical substances, such as sediments, nutrients, fish larvae, and contaminants. The study of the valley circulation is thus important in biological production and contaminant dispersal on the continental shelves.

The scientific publications from this project focus on understanding the basic flow pattern in the Hudson Shelf Valley, the mechanism of asymmetrical flow responses in shelf valleys to along-shelf winds of opposite directions, and the mechanism of asymmetrical internal tide generation in a canyon. Existing observational data from the Hudson Shelf Valley is compiled and analyzed, and analytical and numerical modeling analyses of the valley circulation are conducted. The data analyses reveal that winds tend to drive a stronger up-valley flow than down-valley flow in the Hudson Shelf Valley, which causes the mean flow to be up-valley (Figure 1). This asymmetry in the along-valley flow results from the arresting of the coastal-trapped waves by the wind-driven along-shelf flow, which is a key finding of this study (Figure 2). Both the up- and down-valley flows depend on a number of factors, including the wind stress, Coriolis, bottom friction, and valley geometry. The parameter dependences of the up- and down-valley flows are formulated based on the respective flow dynamics. Another important outcome of this study is the discovery of the asymmetrical generation pattern of internal tides in a canyon. In particular, the intensity of locally generated internal tides tends to be stronger on one side of the canyon than the other (Figure 3), depending on the sense of rotation of the current of the surface tide. Through combining a semi-analytical model and a numerical model, the mechanism of asymmetrical internal tide generation in a canyon is identified.

These results have important implications for studies in related fields. The explanation of the asymmetrical flow response in a shelf valley to ambient along-shelf flows of opposite directions is expected to be applicable to slope canyons. It provides a framework for quantifying the cross-shelf and vertical transport of physical, chemical and biological materials induced by irregular seafloor bathymetry. It is thus important for studies of other shelf physics, shelf biological production, and shelf chemical processes. Discovery of the asymmetrical generation of internal tides in canyons will help improve our understanding of the inhomogeneous mixing on the shelves. It also provides a potential explanation for the observed differences in the sediment distribution and bottom slope on the opposite sides of the canyons. Together, they form a framework for understanding the two-way interaction between the irregular seafloor and circulation and waves in the water column.

To summarize, this project advances both theoretical and observational understanding of flows in submarine valleys and canyons with important implications for related fields. The historical data from the Hudson Shelf Valley compiled in this project is available for the community. The results of this study have also been shared with a broad community through journal publications and conference presentations. The outcome of this study provides a framework for further studies to examine the interactions between seafloor bathymetry and oceanic circulation.
